messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 56 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Dexterous Imitation Made Easy: A Learning-Based Framework for Efficient Dexterous Manipulation

Paper Abstract: Abstract Optimizing behaviors for dexterous manipulation has been a longstanding challenge in robotics, with a variety of methods from model-based control to model-free reinforcement learning having been previously explored in literature. Perhaps one of the most powerful techniques to learn complex manipulation strategies is imitation learning. However, collecting and learning from demonstrations in dexterous manipulation is quite challenging. The complex, high-dimensional action-space involved with multi-finger control often leads to poor sample efficiency of learning-based methods. In this work, we propose ‘Dexterous Imitation Made Easy’ (DIME) a new imitation learning framework for dexterous manipulation. DIME only requires a single RGB camera to observe a human operator and teleoperate our robotic hand. Once demonstrations are collected, DIME employs standard imitation learning methods to train dexterous manipulation policies. On both simulation and real robot benchmarks we demonstrate that DIME can be used to solve complex, in-hand manipulation tasks such as ‘flipping’, ‘spinning’, and ‘rotating’ objects with the Allegro hand. Our framework along with pre-collected demonstrations is publicly available at: https://nyu-robot-learning.github.io/dime.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 56 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 56"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Mind children: The future of robot and human intelligence",
        "How far is the human hand",
        "The sdm hand as a prosthetic terminal device: a feasibility study",
        "Learning dexterous manipulation policies from experience and imitation",
        "Deep dynamics models for learning dexterous manipulation",
        "A system for general in-hand object re-orientation",
        "State of the art robotic grippers and applications",
        "Push-grasping with dexterous hands: Mechanics and a method",
        "Dexterous manipulation using both palm and fingers",
        "Goal directed multi-finger manipulation: Control policies and analysis",
        "Learning dexterous in-hand manipulation",
        "Solving rubik’s cube with a robot hand",
        "Robot see, robot do: An overview of robot imitation",
        "Is imitation learning the route to humanoid robots?",
        "Keyframe-based learning from demonstration",
        "A systematic review of commercial smart gloves: Current status and applications",
        "Dexpilot: Vision based teleoperation of dexterous robotic hand-arm system",
        "Mediapipe hands: On-device real-time hand tracking",
        "Learning complex dexterous manipulation with deep reinforcement learning and demonstrations",
        "Robot juggling: implementation of memory-based learning",
        "The surprising effectiveness of representation learning for visual imitation",
        "Learning strategies in table tennis using inverse reinforcement learning",
        "Deepmpc: Learning deep latent features for model predictive control.",
        "Multiple interactions made easy (mime): Large scale demonstrations data for imitation",
        "Deep imitation learning for complex manipulation tasks from virtual reality teleoperation",
        "Grasping in the wild: Learning 6dof closed-loop grasping from low-cost demonstrations",
        "Visual imitation made easy",
        "Real-time hand-tracking with a color glove",
        "Mobilehand: Real-time 3d hand shape and pose estimation from color image",
        "Dart: Dense articulated real-time tracking",
        "V2v-posenet: Voxel-to-voxel prediction network for accurate 3d hand and human pose estimation from a single depth map",
        "Robotic telekinesis: Learning a robotic hand imitator by watching humans on youtube",
        "Dexmv: Imitation learning for dexterous manipulation from human videos",
        "Dexvip: Learning dexterous grasping with human hand pose priors from video",
        "Alvinn: An autonomous land vehicle in a neural network",
        "Implicit behavioral cloning",
        "End to end learning for self-driving cars",
        "Playful interactions for representation learning",
        "Data as demonstrator with applications to system identification.",
        "A reduction of imitation learning and structured prediction to no-regret online learning",
        "Apprenticeship learning via inverse reinforcement learning",
        "A game-theoretic approach to apprenticeship learning",
        "Optimal control with learned local models: Application to dexterous manipulation",
        "Plan online, learn offline: Efficient learning and exploration via model-based control",
        "Learning latent plans from play",
        "Don’t change the algorithm, change the data: Exploratory data for offline reinforcement learning",
        "Leveraging demonstrations for deep reinforcement learning on robotics problems with sparse rewards",
        "Combining self-supervised learning and imitation for vision-based rope manipulation",
        "State-only imitation learning for dexterous manipulation",
        "A framework for efficient robotic manipulation",
        "Robotic operating system.",
        "A natural policy gradient",
        "Proximal policy optimization algorithms",
        "Bootstrap your own latent-a new approach to self-supervised learning",
        "Robel: Robotics benchmarks for learning with low-cost robots",
        "Mujoco: A physics engine for model-based control"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 56 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Dexterous Imitation Made Easy: A Learning-Based Framework for Efficient Dexterous Manipulation, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
